developmentContext.title: Development Context
developmentContext.content:
Comoros is an archipelago composed of four islands which are, from East to West: Mayotte (370 sq km), Anjouan (424 sq km), Mohéli (290 sq km) and Grand-Comoro (1148 sq km). With an exclusive economic zone of 164 643km square and land area of 1861km square its economy is mainly dependent on farming and fishing. The country is home to 1.1 million people with the urban population making about 29.2% of the population.

There are important gender disparities in Comorian society; for example, women have a Human Development Index and gross national income of 0.519 and $2,300, compared to 0.583 and $3,885 respectively for men. More than 82% of actively employed women work in the informal sector and women are underrepresented in political bodies (only 16.7% of seats in Parliament, 6 percent of the Government’s Cabinet Ministers and 28% of local authorities’ cabinet members). Young people face high unemployment (38 percent in the 18-35 age group are unemployed), are insufficiently trained in sectors with growth potential and there is little support for young entrepreneurs. Persons with disabilities are largely ignored and their needs neglected (more than 60 % have never attended school and 67.3% are economically inactive).

successesInDevelopment.title: Successes in Development
successesInDevelopment.content:
Since 2010, Comoros has experienced accelerated economic growth, reaching 3.7% in 2018. The country joined the lower-middle-income category in 2018 and the medium human development category in 2019 (Human Development Index 0.554, 156th of 189 countries). Between 2000 and 2019, Comoros’ HDI value increased from 0.465 to 0.554, an increase of 19.1 percent. Table A reviews Comoros’ progress in each of the HDI indicators. Between 1990 and 2019, Comoros’ life expectancy at birth increased by 7.6 years, mean years of schooling increased by 2.3 years and expected years of schooling increased by 3.3 years. Comoros’ GNI per capita increased by about 1.4% between 1990 and 2019.

Unified legislation has been set up to include a system for the sustainable management of natural resources established to enable the classification of 27% of the land area and 4.49% of territorial waters as protected areas. Comoros has also gained improved mechanisms for development planning, monitoring and evaluation, with the aim to provide the Comoros with development policies, strategies and other instruments in addition to consolidating peace, democracy and the promotion of human rights. Multi-hazard early warning systems have been developed and operationalized, and resilience of institutions and most vulnerable communities to crises and disasters improved. Improved food security, community resilience to climate changes, and access to employment for youth and women have all improved livelihoods and security.

challengesInDevelopment.title: Challenges in Development
challengesInDevelopment.content:
In 2019, 37.3 percent of Comorians were living in multidimensional poverty and 42.4% were below the national poverty line. Progress remains fragile due to: (a) the volatility of growth and its undiversified base; (b) low exploitation of regional integration opportunities and the potential of green and blue economies; (c) ecological fragility and high vulnerability to climate change and shocks; (d) the country's limited adaptation and mitigation capacity; and (e) lack of preparedness, response and recovery from disasters, as the passage of Cyclone Kenneth and the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic have recently demonstrated. In addition, global governance indicators suggest that this is an area requiring additional attention. Comoros is ranked 38th of 54 countries in the Ibrahim Index of African Governance, having lost 2.6 points between 2010 and 2019.

Comoros requires the acceleration and diversification of growth: economic growth remains fragile in terms of its sources, is insufficient in pace and has led to very little job creation, especially for young people and women. To remedy this, the growth strategy has been designed with an assumed growth rate of around 7%. The low representation of women in decision-making bodies also requires specific measures to ensure their full participation in decision-making.

SDG profile: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/UNSDG/countryprofiles/com

The annual growth rate of real gross domestic product (GDP) per capita increased from -0.2 % in 2000 to 0.7% in 2018.

Land area covered by forest declined from 22.4 % in 2000 to 17.7% in 2020.

In 2018, 2.4 % of the marine environment under national jurisdiction (up to 200 nautical miles from shore) was under protection .

In 2018, 8.0 % of the population relied primarily on clean fuels and technology .

Fixed-broadband internet penetration reached 0.0 per 100 inhabitants in 2004 to 0.2 per 100 inhabitants in 2018.

The proportion of primary schools with access to the internet for pedagogical purposes was 8.0 % in 2017.

In 2018, 82.5 % of the population were covered by at least a 4G mobile network

156/189 Index of human development (2019)

Country Program Document: https://digitallibrary.un.org/record/3932455?ln=en

1. Since 2010, Comoros has experienced accelerated economic growth, reaching 3.7 per cent

in 2018. The country joined the lower-middle-income category in 2018 and the medium

human development category in 2019 (Human Development Index 0.554, 156th of 189

countries). Nevertheless, in 2019, 37.3 per cent of Comorians were living in

multidimensional poverty and 42.4 per cent were below the national poverty line.1 Progress

remains fragile due to: (a) the volatility of growth and its undiversified base; (b) low

exploitation of regional integration opportunities and the potential of green and blue

economies; (c) ecological fragility and high vulnerability to climate change and shocks; (d)

the country's limited adaptation and mitigation capacity; and (e) lack of preparedness,

response and recovery from disasters,2 as the passage of Cyclone Kenneth and the

coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic have recently demonstrated.3 In addition, global

governance indicators suggest that this is an area requiring additional attention. Comoros is

ranked 38th of 54 countries in the Ibrahim Index of African Governance, having lost 2.6 points

between 2010 and 2019.

2. There are important gender disparities in Comorian society; for example, women have a

Human Development Index and gross national income of 0.519 and $2,300, compared to

0.583 and $3,885 respectively for men.4 More than 82 per cent of actively employed women

work in the informal sector5 and women are underrepresented in political bodies (only 16.7

per cent of seats in Parliament, 6 per cent of the Government’s Cabinet Ministers and 28 per

cent of local authorities’ cabinet members). Young people face high unemployment (38 per

cent in the 18-35 age group are unemployed),6 are insufficiently trained in sectors with

growth potential and there is little support for young entrepreneurs. Persons with disabilities

are largely ignored and their needs neglected (more than 60 per cent have never attended

school and 67.3 per cent are economically inactive).7

HDR: https://hdr.undp.org/en/countries/profiles/COM#

2- Human Development Index (HDI)

Comoros’ HDI value for 2019 is 0.554— which put the country in the medium human development category—positioning it at 156 out of 189 countries and territories.

Between 2000 and 2019, Comoros’ HDI value increased from 0.465 to 0.554, an increase of 19.1 percent. Table A reviews Comoros’ progress in each of the HDI indicators. Between 1990 and 2019, Comoros’ life expectancy at birth increased by 7.6 years, mean years of schooling increased by 2.3 years and expected years of schooling increased by 3.3 years. Comoros’ GNI per capita increased by about 1.4 percent between 1990 and 2019.

3- Inequality-adjusted HDI (IHDI)

Comoros’ HDI for 2019 is 0.554. However, when the value is discounted for inequality, the HDI falls to 0.303, a loss of 45.3 percent due to inequality in the distribution of the HDI dimension indices. Gambia and Lesotho show losses due to inequality of 32.5 percent and 27.5 percent, respectively. The average loss due to inequality for medium HDI countries is 26.3 percent and for Sub-Saharan Africa it is 30.5 percent. The Human inequality coefficient for Comoros is equal to 44.2 percent

4- Gender Development Index (GDI)

The 2019 female HDI value for Comoros is 0.519 in contrast with 0.583 for males, resulting in a GDI value of 0.891, placing it into Group 5.

6- Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI)

The most recent survey data that were publicly available for Comoros’ MPI estimation refer to 2012. In Comoros, 37.3 percent of the population (310 thousand people) are multidimensionally poor while an additional 22.3 percent are classified as vulnerable to multidimensional poverty (185 thousand people). The breadth of deprivation (intensity) in Comoros, which is the average deprivation score experienced by people in multidimensional poverty, is 48.5 percent. The MPI, which is the share of the population that is multidimensionally poor, adjusted by the intensity of the deprivations, is 0.181.
